problem:
Let \[p(x,y) =
\begin{cases} x + y &\quad \text{if } x \ge 0 \text{ and } y \ge 0, \\
x - 2y &\quad \text{if } x < 0 \text{ and } y < 0, \\
3x + y &\quad \text{otherwise}.
\end{cases}
\]What is $p(p(1,-1),p(-5,-2))$?
solution:
First, we find $p(1,-1)$. Since it falls into the otherwise category, $p(1,-1) = 3 \cdot 1 - 1 = 2$.

Next, we find $p(-5,-2)$. Since both numbers are negative, it follows that $p(-5,-2) = -5 - 2(-2) = -1$.

Thus, $p(p(1,-1),p(-5,-2)) = p(2,-1)$. This again falls into the otherwise category, and we find that $p(2,-1) = 3 \cdot 2 - 1 = \boxed{5}$.
model_solution:
Step 1: First, calculate $p(1,-1)$, which falls under the "otherwise" category because $1 \ge 0$ and $-1 < 0$. So, $p(1,-1) = 3(1) + (-1) = 2$.
Step 2: Next, calculate $p(-5,-2)$, which falls under the category $x < 0$ and $y < 0$. So, $p(-5,-2) = (-5) - 2(-2) = -1$.
Step 3: Now calculate $p(p(1,-1),p(-5,-2)) = p(2,-1)$, which again falls under the "otherwise" category. So, $p(2,-1) = 3(2) + (-1) = 5$.
Step 4: Now that we have $p(2,-1) = 5$, we have $p(p(1,-1),p(-5,-2)) = p(2,-1) = 5$.
Step 5: $p(2,-1) = 3(2) + (-1) = 5$.
Step 6: $p(2,-1) = 5$.
Step 7: $p(p(1,-1),p(-5,-2)) = 5$.
Final Answer

Step 3: Now calculate $p(p(1,-1),p(-5,-2)) = p(2,-1)$, which again falls under the "otherwise" category. So, $p(2,-1) = 3(2) + (-1) = 5$.
Step 4: Now that we have $p(2,-1) = 5$, we have $p(p(1,-1),p(-5,-2)) = p(2,-1) = 5$.

Step 2: Next, calculate $p(-5,-2)$, which falls under the category $x < 0$ and $y < 0$. So, $p(-5,-2) = (-5) - 2(-2) = -1$.
Step 3: Now calculate $p(p(1,-1),p(-5,-2)) = p(2,-1)$, which again falls under the "otherwise" category. So, $p(2,-1) = 3(2) + (-1) = 5$.
Step 4: Now that we have $p(2,-1) = 5$, we have $p(p(1,-1),p(-5,-2)) = p(2,-1) = 5$.
